se.jguru.nazgul.core.reflection.api.conversion

Annotation Type Converter


  • @Retention(value=RUNTIME)
 @Documented
 @Inherited
 @Target(value={METHOD,CONSTRUCTOR})
public @interface Converter
    Annotation defining a method or constructor accepting a single argument with a given (source) type, and returning a non-void object (called target type). The two typical examples of conversion are illustrated below: 
         class FooConverter {

         @Converter
         public String convert(Foo aFoo) {
             ...
         }

         @Converter
         public Foo convert(String aString) {
             ...
         }
     }
    If constructor conversion is desired, the typical pattern becomes: 
         class Foo {

         @Converter
         public Foo(String aString) {
             ...
         }
     }
    Examples for arguments to the Converter annotation are found within their respective JavaDoc.
    Author:
    Lennart Jörelid, jGuru Europe AB

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Fields and Description
      static int DEFAULT_PRIORITY
      The default priority value, used if no other priority has been supplied.
      static String NO_CONVERTER_METHOD
      The default converterMethod value, used to indicate that no converter method name has been supplied.

    • Optional Element Summary

      Optional Elements 
      Modifier and Type Optional Element and Description
      boolean acceptsNullValues
      Parameter to indicate that this converter method or constructor accepts null values.
      String conditionalConversionMethod
      Name of a method with a single parameter of the same source type as the @Converter-annotated method, and returning a boolean.
      int priority
      Parameter to indicate which priority this converter method or constructor should have.

    • Field Detail

      • DEFAULT_PRIORITY

        public static final int DEFAULT_PRIORITY
        The default priority value, used if no other priority has been supplied.

      • NO_CONVERTER_METHOD

        public static final String NO_CONVERTER_METHOD
        The default converterMethod value, used to indicate that no converter method name has been supplied.

    • Element Detail

      • acceptsNullValues

        public abstract boolean acceptsNullValues
        Parameter to indicate that this converter method or constructor accepts null values. Defaults to false. If this parameter is set to true, your converter [method or constructor] indicates that it should be able to provide a default value in the case of null input values. A typical example is provided below: 
        
     @Converter(acceptsNullValues = true)
     public StringBuffer convert(final String aString) {
          final String bufferValue = aString == null ? "nothing!" : aString;
          return new StringBuffer(bufferValue);
     }
        Returns:
        true if this Converter accepts nulls as values for conversion.
        Default:
        false

      • priority

        public abstract int priority

        Parameter to indicate which priority this converter method or constructor should have. A lower (but positive, until minimum 0) priority implies that this converter will be attempted before a converter with higher priority value. In that sense, the priority should be regarded as the execution index of several converters.

        A typical example for defining a would be:

             class AnotherFooConverter {

         @Converter(priority = 200)
         public String convert(Foo aFoo) {
             ...
         }

         public boolean checkFoo(Foo aFoo) {
             // Find out if the aFoo can be converted by this FooConverter instance.
         }
     }
        Returns:
        the priority of this Converter method or constructor. Members with lower priorities are attempted before higher priority ones.
        Default:
        100

      • conditionalConversionMethod

        public abstract String conditionalConversionMethod

        Name of a method with a single parameter of the same source type as the @Converter-annotated method, and returning a boolean. If present, this conditionalConversionMethod value supplies the name of a method [within the same class as this Converter] which should be invoked to find out if the supplied source object can be converted by this method.

        This attribute is ignored for Constructor Converters. A typical example would be:

             class FooConverter {

         @Converter(conditionalConversionMethod = "checkFoo")
         public String convert(Foo aFoo) {
             ...
         }

         public boolean checkFoo(Foo aFoo) {
             // Find out if the aFoo can be converted by this FooConverter instance.
         }
     }
        Returns:
        Name of a method with a single parameter of the same source type as the @Converter-annotated method, and returning a boolean.
        Default:
        "##NONE##"
